elements.content: Three new inorganic coordination polymers, {[Mn(H2O)6]­[Mn2(H2O)6]­[(Cu6(mna)6]­·6H2O}, 1, {[Mn4(OH)2(H2O)10]­[(Cu6(mna)6]­·8H2O}, 2, and {[Mn2(H2O)5]­[Ag6(Hmna)2(mna)4]­·20H2O}, 3, have been synthesized at room temperature through a sequential crystallization route. In addition, we have also prepared and characterized the molecular precursor [Cu6(Hmna)6]. Compounds 1 and 3 have a two-dimensional structure, whereas 2 has a three-dimensional structure. The formation of 2 has been achieved by minor modification in the synthetic composition, suggesting the subtle relationship between the reactant composition and the structure. The hexanuclear copper and silver cluster cores have Cu···Cu and Ag···Ag distances close to the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu1+ and Ag1+, respectively. The connectivity between [Cu6(mna)6]6– cluster units and Mn2+ ions gives rise to a brucite related layer in 1 and a pcu-net in 2. The [Ag6(Hmna)2­(mna)4]4– cluster in 3, on the other hand, forms a sql-net with Mn2+. Compound 1 exhibits an interesting and reversible hydrochromic behavior, changing from pale yellow to red, on heating at 70 °C or treatment under a vacuum. Electron paramagnetic resonance studies indicate no change in the valence states, suggesting the color change could be due to changes in the coordination environment only. The magnetic studies indicate weak antiferromagnetic behavior. Proton conductivity studies indicate moderate proton migrations in 1 and 3. The present study clearly establishes sequential crystallization as an important pathway for the synthesis of heterometallic coordination polymers.

In addition, we have also prepared and characterized the molecular precursor [Cu6(Hmna)6]. Compounds 1 and 3 have a two-dimensional structure, whereas 2 has a three-dimensional structure. The formation of 2 has been achieved by minor modification in the synthetic composition, suggesting the subtle relationship between the reactant composition and the structure. The hexanuclear copper and silver cluster cores have Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu and Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances close to the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu1+ and Ag1+, respectively. The connectivity between [Cu6(mna)6]6- cluster units and Mn2+ ions gives rise to a brucite related layer in 1 and a pcu-net in 2. The [Ag6(Hmna)2(mna)4]4- cluster in 3, on the other hand, forms a sql-net with Mn2+. Compound 1 exhibits an interesting and reversible hydrochromic behavior, changing from pale yellow to red, on heating at 70 °C or treatment under a vacuum. Electron paramagnetic resonance studies indicate no change in the valence states, suggesting the color change could be due to changes in the coordination environment only. The magnetic studies indicate weak antiferromagnetic behavior. Proton conductivity studies indicate moderate proton migrations in 1 and 3. The present study clearly establishes sequential crystallization as an important pathway for the synthesis of heterometallic coordination polymers.

elements.content:
Stepwise assembly of Cu6 and Ag6 clusters as metalloligands gave two- and three-dimensional heterometallic assemblies, exhibiting reversible hydrochromic behavior.

Introduction

The design and creation of molecular aggregates containing transition metal elements have received much attention in the field of coordination and supramolecular chemistry. Organic ligands with affinity for metals have been employed in the preparation of such molecular aggregates. This approach gives rise to homometallic assemblies in a facile manner. The heterometallic systems, however, were harder to synthesize as it was difficult to control the structure as well as the precise ratio between the participating metallic species. One approach to overcome this difficulty is to employ organic ligands that offer multiple functional groups. In this method, a metal complex or a metalloligand would be formed initially utilizing part of the available functional groups of the participating organic ligand, and the remaining functional groups could be employed for binding with the second metal ion.

Introduction

The design and creation of molecular aggregates containing transition metal elements have received much attention in the field of coordination and supramolecular chemistry. elements.content: It has been shown that thiolate based organic ligands bind with multiple metal centers through well organized sulfur bridges. Such thiolate bridged assemblies can act as a metalloligand to bind with other metal centers forming heterometallic systems. Approaches of this nature have been fruitfully employed to prepare interesting heterometallic molecular aggregates. In this context 2-mercapto nicotinic acid (H 2 mna) has been selected as a suitable ligand, which has two additional functional groups, −COOH and pyridyl nitrogen, apart from the −SH group.

In this context 2-mercapto nicotinic acid (H 2 mna) has been selected as a suitable ligand, which has two additional functional groups, -COOH and pyridyl nitrogen, apart from the -SH group.

elements.content: The knowledge gained from coordination chemistry was utilized during the last two decades in the development of the family of compounds known as metal–organic framework (MOF) or coordination polymer (CP). A majority of the prepared MOFs or CPs are homometallic. Heterometallic systems, on the other hand, are more difficult to synthesize but are attractive for their interesting properties in many areas, such as magnetism, luminescence, catalysis, etc. Such heterometallic MOFs were prepared employing traditional approaches, but gaining control over the composition of the final product was not easy. The more convenient approach to construct heterometallic frameworks is to react a presynthesized metalloligand with a second metal ion. This approach would allow the preparation of compounds with a precise ratio between the participating metal ions. A two-step crystal engineering strategy to generate heterometallic frameworks has been reported recently by Zaworotko and co-workers. The number of such reports are limited, due to the many challenges in assembling the presynthesized components.

elements.content: We were intrigued at the possibility of employing a stepwise synthetic strategy, where the metalloligand and the second metal ion have different geometries, toward the extended frameworks with diverse structures. In designing such extended solids, we employed metalloligands that could bind with another metal in a controlled fashion. Metalloligands having free coordinating sites, other than oxo or cyano groups, were limited toward the assembly of heterometallic systems. In order to realize such systems, two distinct hexanuclear metalloligands [Cu6(mna)6]6– and [Ag6(mna)6]6– were chosen, where the six carboxylate groups are available for binding with the second metal ions. These molecular assemblies have been shown to exhibit significant luminescence behavior due to the d10 closed shell electronic configuration as well as cuprophilic (Cu···Cu) and argentophilic (Ag···Ag) interactions. Heterometallic assemblies employing [Ag6(mna)6]6– have been reported recently. It may be noted that [Cu6(mna)6]6– or [Cu6(Hmna)6] have not been isolated so far, though [Ag6(Hmna)6] was known. As part of the present study, we have stabilized the hexanuclear copper cluster with Hmna ligand. Subsequent crystallization with Mn2+ ion resulted in two distinct heterometallic phases, {[Mn(H2O)6]­[Mn2(H2O)6]­[(Cu6(mna)6]­·6H2O}, 1 and {[Mn4(OH)2(H2O)10]­[(Cu6(mna)6]­·8H2O}, 2. A similar study employing [Ag6(mna)6]6– core yielded {[Mn2(H2O)5]­[Ag6(Hmna)2­(mna)4]­·20H2O}, 3. In this paper, we present the synthesis, structure, and properties of the compounds.

elements.content: The chemicals, CuCl, Cu(OAc)2·2H2O, Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O, MnCl2·4H2O, aqueous NH3 (25%), ethanol, acetonitrile, and dimethylformamide were obtained from SDfine (India), and AgNO3 and 2-mercaptonicotinic acid were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and were used as received. The water used was double distilled through a Millipore membrane.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The chemicals, CuCl, Cu(OAc)2⋅2H2O, Mn(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O, MnCl2⋅4H2O, aqueous NH3 (25%), ethanol, acetonitrile, and dimethylformamide were obtained from SDfine (India), and AgNO3 and 2-mercaptonicotinic acid were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and were used as received. The water used was double distilled through a Millipore membrane.

elements.content: The H 2 mna ligand (0.062 g, 0.4 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of DMF and placed at the bottom of a test tube and carefully layered by a 4 mL CH3CN solution of Cu(OAc)2·2H2O (0.0798 g, 0.4 mmol) with a 4 mL buffer layer (DMF/CH3CN = 1:1). The solutions were allowed to stand at room temperature for about 3 days resulting in orange yellow block crystals of [Cu6(Hmna)6].
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis. [Cu 6 (Hmna) 6 ] 

The H 2 mna ligand (0.062 g, 0.4 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of DMF and placed at the bottom of a test tube and carefully layered by a 4 mL CH3CN solution of Cu(OAc)2⋅2H2O (0.0798 g, 0.4 mmol) with a 4 mL buffer layer (DMF/CH3CN = 1:1). The solutions were allowed to stand at room temperature for about 3 days resulting in orange yellow block crystals of [Cu6(Hmna)6].

elements.content:
Compound 1 was obtained employing a stepwise synthetic strategy employing the metalloligand [Cu6(mna)6]6–.

Preparation of [Cu<sub>6</sub>(<italic toggle="yes">mna</italic>)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>6–</sup> (<italic toggle="yes">Solution A</italic>)

CuCl (0.010 g, 0.1 mmol) and H 2 mna (0.016 g, 0.1 mmol) were mixed with 3 mL of water in a beaker and ultrasonicated for ∼15 min at room temperature. This resulted in an orange yellow precipitate, which was dissolved by the dropwise addition of aqueous NH3 giving rise to a clear yellow solution. Solution B: 0.08 mmol of MnCl2·4H2O (0.0158g) was dissolved in a 3 mL water–ethanol mixture (H2O/EtOH = 2:1). Solution A was taken in a 15 mL test tube. Three milliliters of solution B was then carefully layered on top of solution A, and then the test tube was kept undisturbed at room temperature for 96 h to result in pale yellow trigonal-shaped crystals (yield = 35%, based on Cu). Elemental analysis: Anal. Calcd (%) for 1: C 24.16, H 3.04, N 4.69, S 10.75; found: C 24.34, H 3.50, N 5.04, S 10.47.

elements.content: Compound 2 was prepared by employing a similar procedure by using a higher concentration of MnCl2·4H2O (0.0237g, 0.12 mmol). This resulted in a mixture of both yellow (1) and red crystals (2). In spite of our best efforts, we could not prepare compound 2 in a phase pure form.

Preparation of a Solution of [Ag6(mna)6]6- 

(Solution A) AgNO3 (0.084g, 0.5 mmol) and H 2 mna (0.078 g, 0.5 mmol) were mixed with 3 mL of water and ultrasonicated for 20 min at room temperature. The pale yellow precipitate formed was dissolved by the dropwise addition of aqueous NH3 to give a clear solution. elements.content: Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was recorded in a Thermo Finnigan EA Flash 1112 Series. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded in the 2θ range 5–50° using Cu Kα radiation (Philips X’pert). The observed PXRD patterns were new, and the patterns were entirely consistent with the simulated XRD patterns generated based on the structure determined using the single-crystal X-ray studies for compounds [Cu6(Hmna)6], 1 and 3 (, Figure S1). The IR spectrum was recorded on a KBr pellet (PerkinElmer, SPECTRUM 1000) (, Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Metler-Toledo) was carried out in nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate = 20 mL/min) in the temperature range 30–800 °C (heating rate = 5 °C/min) (, Figure S3). UV–Vis spectra were recorded at room temperature using a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer. Room temperature solid state photoluminescence studies were carried out using a PerkinElmer LS 55 luminescence spectrophotometer. Magnetic studies were carried out in the temperature range of 2–300 K using a SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design, USA). Proton conductivity measurements were carried out on the powdered sample for the compound 1 and 3 by impedance spectroscopy (Alpha, Novocontrol) in the frequency range 1–106 Hz (signal amplitude: 0.12 V). The sample pellets were sandwiched between two stainless steel electrodes and were exposed to a relative humidity of 98% for 24 h before performing the studies. No noticeable changes were observed in the PXRD pattern of the samples (1 and 3) after being exposed to a relative humidity of 98% (, Figure S4). Infrared (IR) spectroscopic studies have been carried out in the mid–IR region (4000 to 400 cm–1) on (PerkinElmer, SPECTRUM 1000). The IR spectra of the compounds 1 and 3 exhibited a broad band in the region of 2900–3500 cm–1, due to the presence of large water molecules (∼3300–3500 cm–1) and aromatic C–H stretching (2900–3100 cm–1) (, Figure S2). For both the compound C–C skeletal stretching appeared at ∼1560 cm–1. In compound 1, singly coordinated −COO– appeared at ∼1580 cm–1. In compound 3, the stretching frequency for uncoordinated −COOH, singly coordinated −COO–, and doubly coordinated −COO– group appeared at ∼1740 cm–1, ∼1580 cm–1, and ∼1540 cm–1, respectively.

Initial Characterization and Physical Measurements

Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was recorded in a Thermo Finnigan EA Flash 1112 Series. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded in the 2θ range 5-50° using Cu Kα radiation (Philips X'pert). The observed PXRD patterns were new, and the patterns were entirely consistent with the simulated XRD patterns generated based on the structure determined using the single-crystal X-ray studies for compounds [Cu6(Hmna)6], 1 and 3 (, Figure S1). The IR spectrum was recorded on a KBr pellet (PerkinElmer, SPECTRUM 1000) (, Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Metler-Toledo) was carried out in nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate = 20 mL/min) in the temperature range 30-800 °C (heating rate = 5 °C/min) (, Figure S3). UV-Vis spectra were recorded at room temperature using a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer. Room temperature solid state photoluminescence studies were carried out using a PerkinElmer LS 55 luminescence spectrophotometer. Magnetic studies were carried out in the temperature range of 2-300 K using a SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design, USA). Proton conductivity measurements were carried out on the powdered sample for the compound 1 and 3 by impedance spectroscopy (Alpha, Novocontrol) in the frequency range 1-106 Hz (signal amplitude: 0.12 V). The sample pellets were sandwiched between two stainless steel electrodes and were exposed to a relative humidity of 98% for 24 h before performing the studies. No noticeable changes were observed in the PXRD pattern of the samples (1 and 3) after being exposed to a relative humidity of 98% (, Figure S4). Infrared (IR) spectroscopic studies have been carried out in the mid-IR region (4000 to 400 cm-1) on (PerkinElmer, SPECTRUM 1000). The IR spectra of the compounds 1 and 3 exhibited a broad band in the region of 2900-3500 cm-1, due to the presence of large water molecules (~3300-3500 cm-1) and aromatic C-H stretching (2900-3100 cm-1) (, Figure S2). For both the compound C-C skeletal stretching appeared at ~1560 cm-1. In compound 1, singly coordinated -COO- appeared at ~1580 cm-1. In compound 3, the stretching frequency for uncoordinated -COOH, singly coordinated -COO-, and doubly coordinated -COO- group appeared at ~1740 cm-1, ~1580 cm-1, and ~1540 cm-1, respectively.

elements.content: A suitable single crystal of each compound was carefully selected under a polarizing microscope and mounted carefully to a thin fiber loop with the help of paratone oil. Single crystal data were collected at 120(2) K on an Oxford Xcalibur (Mova) diffractometer equipped with an EOS CCD detector. The X-ray generator was operated at 50 kV and 0.8 mA using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The cell refinement and data reduction were accomplished using CrysAlis RED. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined using SHELX97 present in the WinGX suit of programs (version 1.63.04a). The positions of aromatic C–H hydrogen atoms in compound 1, 2, and [Cu6(Hmna)6] were initially located from the difference Fourier map, and for the final refinement, they were placed in geometrically ideal positions and refined in the riding mode. In compound 3 the aromatic C–H hydrogen atoms are located and assigned from the difference Fourier map, but the hydrogen positions of the coordinated and lattice water molecules could not be assigned located. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecules in compound 1 could be assigned. In compound 2, the hydrogen atoms of the OH group and water molecules are located except for O14 and O15, where the hydrogen atoms could not be located. The full matrix least–squares refinement against |F 2| was carried out using the WinGx package of programs. The final refinements included atomic positions for all the atoms, anisotropic thermal parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms, and isotropic thermal parameters for all the hydrogen atoms. The highly disordered solvent molecules in compound 2 and the parent metallogligand [Cu6(Hmna)6] were accounted for by using the SQUEEZE option present in the WinGX platon program. The details of the structure solution and final refinement parameters are given in Table . The crystallographic and bond parameters of [Cu6(Hmna)6] are presented in the in Tables S1 and S2, respectively. The CCDC numbers for the compounds [Cu6(Hmna)6], 1, 2, and 3 are , , , , respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Single-Crystal Structure Determination

A suitable single crystal of each compound was carefully selected under a polarizing microscope and mounted carefully to a thin fiber loop with the help of paratone oil. Single crystal data were collected at 120(2) K on an Oxford Xcalibur (Mova) diffractometer equipped with an EOS CCD detector. The X-ray generator was operated at 50 kV and 0.8 mA using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The cell refinement and data reduction were accomplished using CrysAlis RED. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined using SHELX97 present in the WinGX suit of programs (version 1.63.04a). The positions of aromatic C-H hydrogen atoms in compound 1, 2, and [Cu6(Hmna)6] were initially located from the difference Fourier map, and for the final refinement, they were placed in geometrically ideal positions and refined in the riding mode. In compound 3 the aromatic C-H hydrogen atoms are located and assigned from the difference Fourier map, but the hydrogen positions of the coordinated and lattice water molecules could not be assigned located. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecules in compound 1 could be assigned. In compound 2, the hydrogen atoms of the OH group and water molecules are located except for O14 and O15, where the hydrogen atoms could not be located. The full matrix least-squares refinement against |F 2| was carried out using the WinGx package of programs. The final refinements included atomic positions for all the atoms, anisotropic thermal parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms, and isotropic thermal parameters for all the hydrogen atoms. The highly disordered solvent molecules in compound 2 and the parent metallogligand [Cu6(Hmna)6] were accounted for by using the SQUEEZE option present in the WinGX platon program. The details of the structure solution and final refinement parameters are given in Table . The crystallographic and bond parameters of [Cu6(Hmna)6] are presented in the  in Tables S1 and S2, respectively. The CCDC numbers for the compounds [Cu6(Hmna)6], 1, 2, and 3 are , , , , respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

R 1 = Σ∥|F o| – |F c∥|/Σ|F 0|; wR 2 = {Σ|w(F o 2 – F c 2)]/Σ [w(F o 2)2]}1/2. w = 1/[ρ2(F 0)2 + (aP)2 + bP]. P = [max (F o,O) + 2(F c)2]/3, where a = 0.0247 and b = 0.0000 for 1, 3a = 0.0316 and b = 3.9161 for 2, and a = 0.0484 and b = 99.6843 for 3.

In the asymmetric unit of [Cu6(Hmna)6], there are three [Cu(Hmna)] units, forming the centrosymmetric Cu6S6N6 cluster through the crystallographic inversion center (Figure a). Each Cu(I) is coordinated by two sulfur atoms and one nitrogen atom from three Hmna ligands, forming a trigonal geometry. The average Cu–S and Cu–N bond distances are 2.238 and 2.022 Å, respectively (, Tables S2). Six copper centers are arranged in a distorted octahedral geometry (inset of Figure a). The nitrogen atom of Hmna ligand is coordinated to one copper and the μ2-sulfur atom is connected to two different copper centers, which make the Hmna ligand a μ3-bridging ligand. The average Cu···Cu separation between the copper atoms bridged by thiolate sulfur is 3.067 Å and that between two neighboring copper atoms coordinated through nitrogen is 2.793 Å. These Cu···Cu distances are close to the sum of the van der Waals radii of two Cu(I) atoms (2.80 Å), suggesting the presence of cuprophilic (Cu···Cu) interactions. The [Cu6(Hmna)6] cluster is comparable to other reported Cu6S6 core. It may be noted that the six carboxylic acid groups of the neutral hexanuclear copper cluster do not participate in intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions (Figure b). The structure also possesses a number of solvent molecules. Due to the poor quality of the single crystal, we could not locate the solvent molecules. The molecular structure appears to be stabilized through extensive C–H···π interactions. From the packing of [Cu6(Hmna)6] cluster molecules, one can closely visualize the presence of free carboxylic acid groups pointing toward the interlamellar region, which could be useful in bonding with the secondary metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure of [Cu6(Hmna)6]

In the asymmetric unit of [Cu6(Hmna)6], there are three [Cu(Hmna)] units, forming the centrosymmetric Cu6S6N6 cluster through the crystallographic inversion center (Figure a). Each Cu(I) is coordinated by two sulfur atoms and one nitrogen atom from three Hmna ligands, forming a trigonal geometry. The average Cu-S and Cu-N bond distances are 2.238 and 2.022 Å, respectively (, Tables S2). Six copper centers are arranged in a distorted octahedral geometry (inset of Figure a). The nitrogen atom of Hmna ligand is coordinated to one copper and the μ2-sulfur atom is connected to two different copper centers, which make the Hmna ligand a μ3-bridging ligand. The average Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation between the copper atoms bridged by thiolate sulfur is 3.067 Å and that between two neighboring copper atoms coordinated through nitrogen is 2.793 Å. These Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances are close to the sum of the van der Waals radii of two Cu(I) atoms (2.80 Å), suggesting the presence of cuprophilic (Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu) interactions. The [Cu6(Hmna)6] cluster is comparable to other reported Cu6S6 core. It may be noted that the six carboxylic acid groups of the neutral hexanuclear copper cluster do not participate in intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions (Figure b). The structure also possesses a number of solvent molecules. Due to the poor quality of the single crystal, we could not locate the solvent molecules. The molecular structure appears to be stabilized through extensive C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions. From the packing of [Cu6(Hmna)6] cluster molecules, one can closely visualize the presence of free carboxylic acid groups pointing toward the interlamellar region, which could be useful in bonding with the secondary metal ions.

Structure of {[Mn(H2O)6][Mn2(H2O)6][(Cu6(mna)6]⋅6H2O}, 1 

In this compound, hexameric Cu+ clusters, [Cu6(mna)6]6-, are connected with Mn2+ ions forming the two-dimensional (2D) layer structure. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of 1/6 of a [Cu6(mna)6]6- cluster, one [Mn(1)(H2O)]2+ connected to the cluster, one free [Mn(2)(H2O)]2+, and one lattice water molecule. Two Mn2+ ions occupy 6c [Mn(1)] and 3b [Mn(2)] positions with the site multiplicity of 0.33 and 0.16, respectively. The [Cu6(mna)6]6- cluster observed in 1 is comparable to the molecular [Cu6(Hmna)6] cluster described above. The average Cu-S and Cu-N bond distance are 2.232 and 2.004 Å, respectively (, Table S3). The distance between the copper centers bridged by thiolate sulfur is 3.301 Å, whereas the distance between the two neighboring copper centers connected by nitrogen is 2.853 Å, which is closer to the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu+ (2.80 Å). The short Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances give rise to cuprophilic (Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu) interactions.

elements.content: In 1, all the six carboxylates of the [Cu6(mna)6]6– cluster participate in bonding with the Mn2+ [Mn(1)] ions through μ6–η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 binding mode (Figure a). The Mn(1) atoms are in a distorted octahedral coordination environment bonded with three carboxylate oxygen atoms [O(1)] and three water molecules [O(3)] (Figure a). The Mn(1)–O(1) and Mn(1)–O(3) distances are 2.177 and 2.185 Å, respectively. In 1, each Cu6S6N6 cluster is connected with six Mn(1) centers, and each Mn(1) is connected with three Cu6S6N6 clusters forming a anionic layer, {[Mn2(H2O)6]­[(Cu6(mna)6]}2–. This connectivity would gives rise to a (6,3) net, which is the classic honeycomb 2D net. From the TOPOS analysis, in 1, it would be a binodal (6,3) net and the topology would be kgd (Figure b). The point (Schläfli) symbol for this net would be (43)2(46.66.83). A close examination of the layers reveal that the layer is similar to that observed in brucite, Mg(OH)2, and other layered double hydroxides. The 2D anionic layers in 1 are stacked in an ABCABC··· fashion (Figure ). The charge compensation was achieved by the presence of a discrete manganese hexa aqua complex ([Mn(H2O)6]2+), located in between the lamellar sheets (Figure ).

elements.content: Compound 2 also has similar hexameric copper clusters connected through Mn2+ ions. Unlike the structure of 1, here the connectivity gives rise to a three-dimensional (3D) structure. The asymmetric unit contains half [Cu6(mna)6]6– cluster, two manganese ions bridged by one μ3-OH anion, five coordinated and four lattice water molecules. The hexameric copper cluster has average Cu–S and Cu–N bond distances of 2.242 and 2.034 Å, respectively (, Table S3). The average Cu···Cu separations between the copper atoms bridged by the thiolate sulfur is 2.916 Å and that between two neighboring copper atoms coordinated through nitrogen is 2.795 Å. The distances between the copper atoms here are much closer to the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu+ (2.8 Å), leading to stronger cuprophilic interactions. In 2, eight manganese centers are bound with each Cu6S6N6 cluster unit. Of the six carboxylate groups of [Cu6(mna)6]6– unit, two carboxylate groups are connected with both Mn(1) and Mn(2) through a bidentate chelating mode, and the other four are connected with one Mn(1) through a monodentate mode. This leads to a μ8-η2:η2:η1:η1:η1:η1 binding mode for the carboxylates (Figure a). All the Mn2+ ions are in a distorted octahedral environment. The Mn2+ ions form Mn4 clusters through the μ3-OH bridges with Mn–Mn distances of 3.603 and 3.932 Å (Figure b). Similar Mn4 clusters have been observed in many other MOF compounds. Of the two manganese, Mn(1) is connected with three carboxylates from three different clusters, two μ3-OH and one water molecule, whereas Mn(2) is connected with one carboxylate, one μ3-OH, and four water molecules. The existence of μ3-OH was also confirmed by bond valence sum calculations (, Table S4). The Cu6S6N6 clusters are connected with four Mn4 clusters through four carboxylates forming a infinite 2D layer (Figure a). The other two carboxylates participate in connecting the 2D layers, thereby generating the overall 3D structure (Figure b). From the node-net description, each Cu6S6N6 cluster is connected to six Mn4 clusters and vice versa, which would give rise to a (6,6) net (, Figure S5), giving rise to a pcu topology with the point (Schlafli) symbol of {412.63}.

elements.content: Structure of 3 consists of [Ag6(Hmna)2­(mna)4]4– clusters instead of [Cu6(mna)6]6– cluster. Here the clusters are bonded with [Mn2O6(H2O)5] dimer units forming the 2D structure. The asymmetric unit contains half [Ag6(Hmna)2­(mna)4]4– cluster, one Mn2+ ion, two coordinated water molecules, one bridging water molecule with half occupancy, and 10 lattice water molecules. The silver atoms, in trigonal geometry, are coordinated with two thiolate sulfur atoms and one nitrogen atom from three different mna ligands with average Ag–S and Ag–N bond distances of 2.483 and 2.289 Å, respectively (, Table S3). The distance between the silver atoms are in the range of 2.944–3.483 Å within the octahedral Ag6S6N6 core (inset of Figure a). This indicates reasonable argentophilic (Ag···Ag) interactions (, Table S3). Similar Ag···Ag interactions have been observed in other related structures. Of the six carboxylic acid groups, four carboxylates (−COO) participate in bonding with Mn2+ ions, and the remaining two are free carboxylic acid groups (−COOH). Among the four carboxylate groups, two carboxylate units bind with Mn2+ ions through both the oxygen atoms, whereas the other two bind through only one oxygen atom leaving the other oxygen atom free. This gives rise to the coordination mode for the carboxylates as μ6-η2:η2:η1:η1 within the metalloligand [Ag6(Hmna)2(mna)4]4– (Figure a). The Mn2+ ion is connected with the neighboring Mn2+ ion via a μ2-H2O, which was also verified by bond valence sum calculations (, Table S4), forming a dimer with Mn–Mn distances of 3.675 Å. All the Mn2+ ions are octahedrally coordinated through three oxygen from three carboxylates, two water molecules, and one bridging water molecule. The average Mn–O distance is 2.188 Å (, Table S3).

elements.content: In 3, each Ag6S6N6 cluster is connected with four manganese dimer units, and each manganese dimer unit is also connected with four Ag6S6N6 cluster units giving rise to a neutral 2D structure, {[Mn2(H2O)5]­[Ag6(Hmna)2­(mna)4]­·20H2O} (Figure b). The interlamellar space contains extra framework lattice water molecules, which are close with O···O distances of ∼2.7 Å. The close proximity between the water molecules in 3 gives rise to extended 2D water sheets (Figure ). There have been many reports of the presence of water clusters and 1D tapes within the channels and voids in MOFs, but the formation of water sheets is not common. The 2D water sheets are not fully perpendicular to the inorganic layer, but are tilted at an angle of ∼45° (, Figure S6a). From a topological view, the inorganic layers have 4:4 connectivity, which has been observed in many MOF compounds. A TOPOS analysis indicate that this is sql topology with a point (Schlafli) symbol of (44.62). The 2D inorganic layers are arranged one over the other in a ABAB··· fashion (, Figure S6b). The presence of lattice water molecules, which form water sheets, the coordinated water molecules along with carboxylic acid groups suggest the possibility of hydrogen bond interactions. In addition, C–H···π interactions between the mna ligands have also been noted in the structure. It is likely that the weak interactions contribute significantly to the stability of the structure.

elements.content: As part of the present study, three new framework compounds, {[Mn(H2O)6]­[Mn2(H2O)6]­[(Cu6(mna)6]­·6H2O}, 1, {[Mn4(OH)2(H2O)10]­[(Cu6(mna)6]­·8H2O}, 2, and {[Mn2(H2O)5]­[Ag6(Hmna)2(mna)4]­·20H2O}, 3, have been isolated containing hexameric metal (Cu, Ag) cluster units acting as a metalloligand. In addition, we have also been successful in isolating the molecular [Cu6(Hmna)6] cluster unit as well. The use of stepwise crystallization has not been explored much in the field of coordination polymers, and the present compounds add to the growing number of compounds prepared employing such methods. The formation of metal cluster units acting as a metalloligand has been described earlier. Recently Zaworotko and co-workers have employed a sequential crystal engineering approach utilizing a number of metal clusters of different geometries as a metalloligand. The octahedral hexameric silver metal centers of the type described here have also been employed in the formation of new frameworks. It appears that the use of 2-mercapto nicotinic acid (Hmna) results in the assembly of structures involving a second metal. The molecular [Cu6(mna)6]6– cluster has six carboxylate units that are available for binding with the secondary metal ions. In the present study, we find that all the six carboxylate units are utilized in bonding with Mn2+ ionssix in 1 and eight in 2. The use of [Ag6(Hmna)2­(mna)4]4– clusters on the other hand leads to the binding with Mn2+ ions through only four carboxylate units, similar binding with secondary metal ions involving four carboxylates have been observed before though the binding modes were different (, Table S5). The present study suggests that the [Cu6(mna)6]6– cluster could be a better metalloligand compared to [Ag6(mna)6]6– as the former binds with a larger number of Mn centers. It is likely that the near van der Waals Cu···Cu distances observed in the Cu6 clusters could make the cuprophilic (Cu···Cu) interactions stronger compared to the argentophilic (Ag···Ag) interactions in the Ag6 cluster. This in turn could be helpful for the six peripheral carboxylates to participate in binding with the secondary metal ions in 1 and 2. It may be noted that when the Cu···Cu distances are shorter, more Mn2+ ions bind with the carboxylates as observed in compound 2. This observation suggests that the short metal–metal distances within the hexameric clusters could have a distinct role toward the reactivity of the metalloligand. It is likely that the cuprophilic and argentophilic interactions could be harnessed gainfully in the stabilization of new framework structures.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

As part of the present study, three new framework compounds, {[Mn(H2O)6][Mn2(H2O)6][(Cu6(mna)6]⋅6H2O}, 1, {[Mn4(OH)2(H2O)10][(Cu6(mna)6]⋅8H2O}, 2, and {[Mn2(H2O)5][Ag6(Hmna)2(mna)4]⋅20H2O}, 3, have been isolated containing hexameric metal (Cu, Ag) cluster units acting as a metalloligand. In addition, we have also been successful in isolating the molecular [Cu6(Hmna)6] cluster unit as well. The use of stepwise crystallization has not been explored much in the field of coordination polymers, and the present compounds add to the growing number of compounds prepared employing such methods. The formation of metal cluster units acting as a metalloligand has been described earlier. Recently Zaworotko and co-workers have employed a sequential crystal engineering approach utilizing a number of metal clusters of different geometries as a metalloligand. The octahedral hexameric silver metal centers of the type described here have also been employed in the formation of new frameworks. It appears that the use of 2-mercapto nicotinic acid (Hmna) results in the assembly of structures involving a second metal. The molecular [Cu6(mna)6]6- cluster has six carboxylate units that are available for binding with the secondary metal ions. In the present study, we find that all the six carboxylate units are utilized in bonding with Mn2+ ionssix in 1 and eight in 2. The use of [Ag6(Hmna)2(mna)4]4- clusters on the other hand leads to the binding with Mn2+ ions through only four carboxylate units, similar binding with secondary metal ions involving four carboxylates have been observed before though the binding modes were different (, Table S5). The present study suggests that the [Cu6(mna)6]6- cluster could be a better metalloligand compared to [Ag6(mna)6]6- as the former binds with a larger number of Mn centers. It is likely that the near van der Waals Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances observed in the Cu6 clusters could make the cuprophilic (Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu) interactions stronger compared to the argentophilic (Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag) interactions in the Ag6 cluster. This in turn could be helpful for the six peripheral carboxylates to participate in binding with the secondary metal ions in 1 and 2. It may be noted that when the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances are shorter, more Mn2+ ions bind with the carboxylates as observed in compound 2. This observation suggests that the short metal-metal distances within the hexameric clusters could have a distinct role toward the reactivity of the metalloligand. It is likely that the cuprophilic and argentophilic interactions could be harnessed gainfully in the stabilization of new framework structures.

elements.content: Structurally, the three compounds along with the molecular precursor [Cu6(Hmna)6] makes an interesting comparison. The close resemblance between the packing structure of [Cu6(Hmna)6] and compounds 1 and 2 is unmistakable. The close scrutiny of the structural arrangements clearly indicates that we have been successful in our sequential assembly of heterometallic inorganic coordination polymers. The molecular complex [Cu6(Hmna)6] can easily react with a secondary metal ion to form the layer structure observed in 1. It may be noted that during the formation of 1 from [Cu6(Hmna)6], the Mn2+ ions bind in such a way that they are above and below the plane of the hexameric copper clusters. A schematic of the possible formation of 1 from the molecular hexameric [Cu6(Hmna)6] cluster is shown in Scheme . The layer structure of 1 is also interesting. The (6,3) net observed in 1 is common with many layered compounds. Presently the structure of 1 is similar to that observed in brucite and many other layered double hydroxides (LDHs) (, Figure S7). The LDHs are known to have cationic layers with intercalated anions. In 1, we find that the layers are anionic, and the interlamellar species is cationic (, Figure S8). The hexa aqua manganese [Mn(H2O)6]2+ ions appear to occupy positions that are similar to the anions in LDH. Anionic layers have been commonly observed in many open framework compounds with the charge compensation achieved by the intercalating organic amine cations. Our efforts to replace the [Mn(H2O)6]2+ in 1 were not successful, which is similar to the failed attempts at replacing the cationic amine molecules in many of the open-framework phosphate and related compounds.

The structure of 2 appears more fascinating as it forms a pcu related net structure. It has been suggested that the cluster based compounds generally arrange in simple structures as shown by Muller and co-workers in many molybdenum based clusters compounds. In MOFs, the pcu structure appears to be common. This is the first time, to our knowledge, the Cu6 cluster units have been combined with Mn4 cluster units to form an extended 3D structure with a pcu net.

elements.content: The use of hexanuclear silver cluster with 2-mercaptonicotinic acid have been attempted before, and number of such studies are known (, Table S5). The hexanuclear silver clusters with mna ligand are known with neutral, −2 and −6 charge states (, Table S5). In the present study, we have obtained [Ag6(Hmna)2(mna)4]4– cluster with a new charge state of −4, which resulted in the isolation of 3. Of the known compounds, prepared using [Ag6(mna)6]6– clusters, only {[Zn3(en)3(H2O)4]­[Ag6(mna)6]·8H2O} n appears to be similar to that of 3. In this compound, Ag6 cluster units are connected with both octahedral, [Zn(en)0.5(H2O)2]2+ and tetrahedral [Zn(en)2]2+ components of Zn forming a 2D layer (, Figure S9). The ethylenediamine units bound with the Zn-centers are terminal, and the interlamellar space is occupied by water molecules, which forms a 1D chain. In 3, the layers are separated by guest water molecules that form a 2D sheet (, Figure S6a).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) has been carried out in nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate = 20 mL/min) in the temperature range 30–800 °C (heating rate = 5 °C/min). In the case of compound 1, {[Mn(H2O)6]­[Mn2(H2O)6]­[(Cu6(mna)6]­·6H2O}, the initial weight loss of ∼11.7% observed in the temperature range of 30–70 °C may be due to loss of the six lattice and six coordinated water molecules (calc. 12%) (, Figure S3a). The second weight loss of ∼5.8% observed in the range of 70–200 °C may be due to the loss of the remaining six coordinated water molecules (calc. 6%). A continuous weight loss of ∼47.9% observed in the range 200–800 °C may be due to loss of the mna ligands (calc. 51.3%). The final products after the TGA studies were found to be CuO (JCPDS: 80-0076) and CuMn2O4 (JCPDS: 84-0543) (, Figure S10a). We have not been successful in isolating compound 2 as a pure phase, which prevented us from characterizing further. Compound 3, {[Mn2(H2O)5]­[Ag6(Hmna)2­(mna)4]·20H2O}, exhibited a weight loss of ∼18% in the range of 30–230 °C, which may be due to the loss of all the lattice water molecules (calc. 17%) (, Figure S3b). After 230 °C, a continuous weight loss of ∼49% was observed up to 750 °C, which may be due to the loss of the coordinated water molecules and the mna ligands (calc. 47.5%). The final calcined products were found to be a mixture of metallic Ag (JCPDS: 89-4837) and Mn3O4 (JCPDS: 89-4837) (, Figure S10b).

Thermogravimetric Studies

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) has been carried out in nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate = 20 mL/min) in the temperature range 30-800 °C (heating rate = 5 °C/min). In the case of compound 1, {[Mn(H2O)6][Mn2(H2O)6][(Cu6(mna)6]⋅6H2O}, the initial weight loss of ~11.7% observed in the temperature range of 30-70 °C may be due to loss of the six lattice and six coordinated water molecules (calc. 12%) (, Figure S3a). The second weight loss of ~5.8% observed in the range of 70-200 °C may be due to the loss of the remaining six coordinated water molecules (calc. 6%). A continuous weight loss of ~47.9% observed in the range 200-800 °C may be due to loss of the mna ligands (calc. 51.3%). The final products after the TGA studies were found to be CuO (JCPDS: 80-0076) and CuMn2O4 (JCPDS: 84-0543) (, Figure S10a). We have not been successful in isolating compound 2 as a pure phase, which prevented us from characterizing further. Compound 3, {[Mn2(H2O)5][Ag6(Hmna)2(mna)4]⋅20H2O}, exhibited a weight loss of ~18% in the range of 30-230 °C, which may be due to the loss of all the lattice water molecules (calc. 17%) (, Figure S3b). After 230 °C, a continuous weight loss of ~49% was observed up to 750 °C, which may be due to the loss of the coordinated water molecules and the mna ligands (calc. 47.5%). The final calcined products were found to be a mixture of metallic Ag (JCPDS: 89-4837) and Mn3O4 (JCPDS: 89-4837) (, Figure S10b).

elements.content: During the thermal stability study of compound 1, a distinct color change from pale yellow to dark red was observed at 70 °C. Compound 1 was also found to turn dark red under a vacuum (Figure ). The red color, obtained by applying either heat or vacuum, exhibits subtle changes in the powder XRD pattern (, Figure S11). In addition, the red compound was found to be stable at room temperature under dry conditions and changes to yellow on exposure to moisture. This suggests that 1 could exhibit hydrochromic behavior due to the loss of solvents. Hydrochromic behavior has been observed before in some MOFs. It is likely that the red compound could be a partially dehydrated form of compound 1. Our efforts to investigate the red color phase of compound 1 employing in situ single crystal X-ray diffraction method was not successful as the sample loses the single crystalline nature during the dehydration. To our surprise, we did not observe such color changes in 3 (, Figure S12). For compound 1, at 70 °C six coordinated water molecules are lost along with lattice water molecules, which could lead to local changes in the structure resulting in the observed color change. For compound 3, only lattice waters are lost from the system, which may not lead to changes in the overall structure.

elements.content: The UV–vis absorption spectra of compounds have been recorded in solid state at room temperature. The absorption bands in the range of 200–500 nm for compound 1, 3 and the molecular precursor [Cu6(Hmna)6] are due to the intraligand π–π* transitions of the mna ligand. The free ligand also exhibits similar absorption bands (, Figure S13). In compound 1, the presence of discrete [Mn(H2O)6]2+ units produces weak absorption around 400 nm. Similar absorption bands have been observed before involving hexa aqua manganese. The partially dehydrated red compound, obtained from 1, exhibits a new absorption band around 505 nm (, Figure S13). It is likely that the loss of water molecules leads to changes at the coordination of Mn2+ ions. In addition, the removal of water molecules could also affect the Cu···Cu distances within the Cu6 core leading to changes in the band gap between the excited and the ground state. Our electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) investigations did not reveal any changes in the oxidation state in any of the participating metal ions (Cu1+ and Mn2+). This suggests that the origin for the color change from yellow to red could be purely due to the coordination changes. The lack of structural details on the red compound posed restrictions on probing further into the origin of the color change in 1.
elements.clean_text:
Absorbance and Photoluminescence Properties

The UV-vis absorption spectra of compounds have been recorded in solid state at room temperature. The absorption bands in the range of 200-500 nm for compound 1, 3 and the molecular precursor [Cu6(Hmna)6] are due to the intraligand π-π* transitions of the mna ligand. The free ligand also exhibits similar absorption bands (, Figure S13). In compound 1, the presence of discrete [Mn(H2O)6]2+ units produces weak absorption around 400 nm. Similar absorption bands have been observed before involving hexa aqua manganese. The partially dehydrated red compound, obtained from 1, exhibits a new absorption band around 505 nm (, Figure S13). It is likely that the loss of water molecules leads to changes at the coordination of Mn2+ ions. In addition, the removal of water molecules could also affect the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances within the Cu6 core leading to changes in the band gap between the excited and the ground state. Our electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) investigations did not reveal any changes in the oxidation state in any of the participating metal ions (Cu1+ and Mn2+). This suggests that the origin for the color change from yellow to red could be purely due to the coordination changes. The lack of structural details on the red compound posed restrictions on probing further into the origin of the color change in 1.

elements.content: The emission spectra of the molecular precursor [Cu6(Hmna)6] and compound 1 was found to be comparable when excited using a wavelength of 260 nm (Figure ). The emission bands observed in the range of 300–530 nm can be assigned to the intraligand emission from the mna ligands along with the d–d transitions of Mn2+ ions. The intense low energy emission band at 665 nm observed for the [Cu6(Hmna)6] cluster could be due to the cluster centered transitions mixed with ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transitions. Similar emission bands have been observed before in compounds based on CuI–thiolate clusters. The low energy emission band exhibits a small blue shift in compound 1 (640 nm) compared to [Cu6(Hmna)6] cluster (665 nm). It is likely that the incorporation of Mn2+ ions modifies the LMCT and the cluster centered emission. The luminescence performance of the partially dehydrated 1 (red colored) is striking as the low energy emission band intensity is significantly quenched (Figure ). This could be due to the possible changes in the Cu···Cu distances of the Cu6 core during the dehydration along with the possible geometry changes around the Mn2+ ions. It has been suggested earlier that the Cu···Cu interactions could be a crucial parameter in determining the luminescence behavior of compounds containing Cu1 clusters.

elements.content: The emission bands for compound 3 were observed at ∼530, ∼485, ∼460, and ∼445 nm after excitation at 365 nm (, Figure S14). The emission bands in the range of 440–490 nm may be due to the intraligand emissions from the mna ligands along with the d–d transitions of Mn2+ ions. The emission at 530 nm may be due to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) mixed with the metal-centered (d–s/d–p) transitions of the Ag6 core. This emission compares well with those observed for other compounds based on [Ag6(mna)6]6– core. It may be noted that the low energy emission band for the [Cu6(Hmna)6] cluster appears at a much lower energy (665 nm) compared to the [Ag6(mna)6]6– (550 nm). A similar trend has been observed for the [Cu(mtc)]6 and the [Ag(mtc)]6 (mtc = di-n-propylmonothiocarbamate) compounds earlier.

elements.content: The EPR spectra were recorded on the powdered sample using a X-band frequency at room temperature. The pale yellow compound 1 as well as the partially dehydrated red sample of 1 exhibit isotropic EPR spectra with identical g value of 2.017 (Figure ). This indicates that the manganese is present as Mn2+ ion in both the compounds. This observation also supports our view that the partially dehydrated 1 possesses structural distortion around the Mn2+ ions only. Compound 3 also exhibits similar isotropic EPR spectra with a g value of 2.004 (Figure ).

EPR and Magnetic Properties

The pale yellow compound 1 as well as the partially dehydrated red sample of 1 exhibit isotropic EPR spectra with identical g value of 2.017 (Figure ). This indicates that the manganese is present as Mn2+ ion in both the compounds. elements.content: Magnetic studies have been carried out in the temperature range 2–300 K using a SQUID magnetometer. The plots of χM T versus T of compounds 1 and 3 are shown in Figure . The χM T values (1000 Oe) at room temperature were found to be 13.99 and 7.87 emu mol–1 K for 1 and 3, respectively. These values are close to the expected spin-only values of 13.13 and 8.75 emu mol–1 K, for the magnetically isolated three Mn2+ ions in 1 and two Mn2+ ions in 3, respectively. From a Curie–Weiss fit (1/χ M versus T) in the temperature range of 2–300 K, θp values of −4.6 and −2.3 K, were obtained for 1 and 3, respectively (inset of Figure ). The low negative values of θp suggest that the interactions between the isolated manganese centers are weak and antiferromagnetic in nature. As expected, the Cu6 as well as the Ag6 centers do not play any role in the magnetic exchanges between the Mn2+ ions in both compounds.

elements.content: The presence of a number of lattice water molecules in 1 and 3 suggested the possibility of possible proton conductivity behavior in these compounds. To examine the proton conductivity behavior, AC impedance studies were carried out under a relative humidity of 98% at room temperature. From the Nyquist plots, proton conductivity values of 1.12 × 10–6 Ω–1 cm–1 and 1.78 × 10–5 Ω–1 cm–1 for compounds 1 and 3, respectively, were observed (Figure ). Similar values have been observed before.
elements.clean_text:
Proton Conductivity

The presence of a number of lattice water molecules in 1 and 3 suggested the possibility of possible proton conductivity behavior in these compounds. To examine the proton conductivity behavior, AC impedance studies were carried out under a relative humidity of 98% at room temperature. From the Nyquist plots, proton conductivity values of 1.12 × 10-6 Ω-1 cm-1 and 1.78 × 10-5 Ω-1 cm-1 for compounds 1 and 3, respectively, were observed (Figure ). Similar values have been observed before.

elements.content: In conclusion, the synthesis, structure, and characterization of heterometallic coordination polymers using Cu6S6N6 and Ag6S6N6 core as metalloligands through a sequential crystallization has been accomplished. A molecular cluster, [Cu6(Hmna)6], has been isolated, structurally characterized, and shown to act as a metalloligand in the assembly of two distinct heterometallic compounds, {[Mn(H2O)6]­[Mn2(H2O)6]­[(Cu6(mna)6]­·6H2O}, 1, and {[Mn4(OH)2(H2O)10]­[(Cu6(mna)6]­·8H2O}, 2, with 2D and 3D structures, respectively. The use of Ag6 cluster, [Ag6(mna)6]6–, gives rise to another 2D compound, {[Mn2(H2O)5]­[Ag6(Hmna)2(mna)4]­·20H2O}, 3. The cuprophilic or argentophilic interactions appear to have a role in the formation of the heterometallic assemblies reported herein. It is likely that more examples would be required to conclude further on the findings of this study. The observation of hydrochromism in 1 suggests that the heterometallic assemblies would find use as moisture sensors. Structurally, the present heterometallic coordination polymers provide a rich diversity in the overall net structures. Presently, we have isolated compounds with brucite related (1), primitive cubic related (2), and a square network (3). It is clear that the use of metalloligand for the assembly of heterometallic coordination polymers is likely to provide a rich diversity in composition as well as structures. Work toward this goal is in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, the synthesis, structure, and characterization of heterometallic coordination polymers using Cu6S6N6 and Ag6S6N6 core as metalloligands through a sequential crystallization has been accomplished. A molecular cluster, [Cu6(Hmna)6], has been isolated, structurally characterized, and shown to act as a metalloligand in the assembly of two distinct heterometallic compounds, {[Mn(H2O)6][Mn2(H2O)6][(Cu6(mna)6]⋅6H2O}, 1, and {[Mn4(OH)2(H2O)10][(Cu6(mna)6]⋅8H2O}, 2, with 2D and 3D structures, respectively. The use of Ag6 cluster, [Ag6(mna)6]6-, gives rise to another 2D compound, {[Mn2(H2O)5][Ag6(Hmna)2(mna)4]⋅20H2O}, 3. The cuprophilic or argentophilic interactions appear to have a role in the formation of the heterometallic assemblies reported herein. It is likely that more examples would be required to conclude further on the findings of this study. The observation of hydrochromism in 1 suggests that the heterometallic assemblies would find use as moisture sensors. Structurally, the present heterometallic coordination polymers provide a rich diversity in the overall net structures. Presently, we have isolated compounds with brucite related (1), primitive cubic related (2), and a square network (3). It is clear that the use of metalloligand for the assembly of heterometallic coordination polymers is likely to provide a rich diversity in composition as well as structures. Work toward this goal is in progress.

cln_elements.content:
The H 2 mna ligand (0.062 g, 0.4 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of DMF and placed at the bottom of a test tube and carefully layered by a 4 mL CH3CN solution of Cu(OAc)2·2H2O (0.0798 g, 0.4 mmol) with a 4 mL buffer layer (DMF/CH3CN = 1:1). The solutions were allowed to stand at room temperature for about 3 days resulting in orange yellow block crystals of [Cu6(Hmna)6].

Compound 1 was obtained employing a stepwise synthetic strategy employing the metalloligand [Cu6(mna)6]6–.

Preparation of [Cu<sub>6</sub>(<italic toggle="yes">mna</italic>)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>6–</sup> (<italic toggle="yes">Solution A</italic>)

CuCl (0.010 g, 0.1 mmol) and H 2 mna (0.016 g, 0.1 mmol) were mixed with 3 mL of water in a beaker and ultrasonicated for ∼15 min at room temperature. This resulted in an orange yellow precipitate, which was dissolved by the dropwise addition of aqueous NH3 giving rise to a clear yellow solution. Solution B: 0.08 mmol of MnCl2·4H2O (0.0158g) was dissolved in a 3 mL water–ethanol mixture (H2O/EtOH = 2:1). Solution A was taken in a 15 mL test tube. Three milliliters of solution B was then carefully layered on top of solution A, and then the test tube was kept undisturbed at room temperature for 96 h to result in pale yellow trigonal-shaped crystals (yield = 35%, based on Cu). Elemental analysis: Anal. Calcd (%) for 1: C 24.16, H 3.04, N 4.69, S 10.75; found: C 24.34, H 3.50, N 5.04, S 10.47.

Preparation of a Solution of [Ag<sub>6</sub>(<italic toggle="yes">mna</italic>)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>6–</sup>

(Solution A) AgNO3 (0.084g, 0.5 mmol) and H 2 mna (0.078 g, 0.5 mmol) were mixed with 3 mL of water and ultrasonicated for 20 min at room temperature. The pale yellow precipitate formed was dissolved by the dropwise addition of aqueous NH3 to give a clear solution. (Solution B) Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O (0.123g, 0.5 mmol) was taken in a 3 mL water–ethanol mixture (H2O/EtOH = 2:1). Three milliliters of Solution B was carefully layered on top of Solution A containing 3 mL of ethanol–water buffer layer in a test tube and kept undisturbed at room temperature for 96 h to result in colorless block-shaped crystals of 3 (yield = 50%, based on Ag). Elemental analysis: Anal. Calcd (%) for 3: C 20.31, H 3.31, N 3.94, S 9.04; found: C 20.27, H 3.51, N 4.12, S 9.10.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis. [Cu 6 (Hmna) 6 ] 

The H 2 mna ligand (0.062 g, 0.4 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL of DMF and placed at the bottom of a test tube and carefully layered by a 4 mL CH3CN solution of Cu(OAc)2⋅2H2O (0.0798 g, 0.4 mmol) with a 4 mL buffer layer (DMF/CH3CN = 1:1). The solutions were allowed to stand at room temperature for about 3 days resulting in orange yellow block crystals of [Cu6(Hmna)6].

Compound 1 was obtained employing a stepwise synthetic strategy employing the metalloligand [Cu6(mna)6]6-.

Preparation of [Cu6(mna)6]6- (Solution A)

CuCl (0.010 g, 0.1 mmol) and H 2 mna (0.016 g, 0.1 mmol) were mixed with 3 mL of water in a beaker and ultrasonicated for ~15 min at room temperature. This resulted in an orange yellow precipitate, which was dissolved by the dropwise addition of aqueous NH3 giving rise to a clear yellow solution. Solution B: 0.08 mmol of MnCl2⋅4H2O (0.0158g) was dissolved in a 3 mL water-ethanol mixture (H2O/EtOH = 2:1). Solution A was taken in a 15 mL test tube. Three milliliters of solution B was then carefully layered on top of solution A, and then the test tube was kept undisturbed at room temperature for 96 h to result in pale yellow trigonal-shaped crystals (yield = 35%, based on Cu). Elemental analysis: Anal. Calcd (%) for 1: C 24.16, H 3.04, N 4.69, S 10.75; found: C 24.34, H 3.50, N 5.04, S 10.47.

Preparation of a Solution of [Ag6(mna)6]6- 

(Solution A) AgNO3 (0.084g, 0.5 mmol) and H 2 mna (0.078 g, 0.5 mmol) were mixed with 3 mL of water and ultrasonicated for 20 min at room temperature. The pale yellow precipitate formed was dissolved by the dropwise addition of aqueous NH3 to give a clear solution. (Solution B) Mn(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O (0.123g, 0.5 mmol) was taken in a 3 mL water-ethanol mixture (H2O/EtOH = 2:1). Three milliliters of Solution B was carefully layered on top of Solution A containing 3 mL of ethanol-water buffer layer in a test tube and kept undisturbed at room temperature for 96 h to result in colorless block-shaped crystals of 3 (yield = 50%, based on Ag). Elemental analysis: Anal. Calcd (%) for 3: C 20.31, H 3.31, N 3.94, S 9.04; found: C 20.27, H 3.51, N 4.12, S 9.10.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) has been carried out in nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate = 20 mL/min) in the temperature range 30–800 °C (heating rate = 5 °C/min). In the case of compound 1, {[Mn(H2O)6]­[Mn2(H2O)6]­[(Cu6(mna)6]­·6H2O}, the initial weight loss of ∼11.7% observed in the temperature range of 30–70 °C may be due to loss of the six lattice and six coordinated water molecules (calc. 12%) (, Figure S3a). The second weight loss of ∼5.8% observed in the range of 70–200 °C may be due to the loss of the remaining six coordinated water molecules (calc. 6%). A continuous weight loss of ∼47.9% observed in the range 200–800 °C may be due to loss of the mna ligands (calc. 51.3%). The final products after the TGA studies were found to be CuO (JCPDS: 80-0076) and CuMn2O4 (JCPDS: 84-0543) (, Figure S10a). We have not been successful in isolating compound 2 as a pure phase, which prevented us from characterizing further. Compound 3, {[Mn2(H2O)5]­[Ag6(Hmna)2­(mna)4]·20H2O}, exhibited a weight loss of ∼18% in the range of 30–230 °C, which may be due to the loss of all the lattice water molecules (calc. 17%) (, Figure S3b). After 230 °C, a continuous weight loss of ∼49% was observed up to 750 °C, which may be due to the loss of the coordinated water molecules and the mna ligands (calc. 47.5%). The final calcined products were found to be a mixture of metallic Ag (JCPDS: 89-4837) and Mn3O4 (JCPDS: 89-4837) (, Figure S10b).

Proton Conductivity

The presence of a number of lattice water molecules in 1 and 3 suggested the possibility of possible proton conductivity behavior in these compounds. To examine the proton conductivity behavior, AC impedance studies were carried out under a relative humidity of 98% at room temperature. From the Nyquist plots, proton conductivity values of 1.12 × 10–6 Ω–1 cm–1 and 1.78 × 10–5 Ω–1 cm–1 for compounds 1 and 3, respectively, were observed (Figure ). Similar values have been observed before.
